title: I'm Switching to AMD - AMD GPU Challenge Part 1
description: Thank you Seasonic for making today's video possible. Check out their Prime TX 1000 Power Supply at   Its been over a DECADE since Ive run an AMD graphics card in my system, but with me swearing off the 40 series from NVIDIA, it looks like its my only option for an upgrade this cycle.  Discuss on the forum:   Buy a GIGABYTE AORUS Radeon RX 7900 XTX:   Purchases made through some store links may provide some compensation to Linus Media Group.   GET MERCH:   LTX 2023 TICKETS AVAILABLE NOW:   GET EXCLUSIVE CONTENT ON FLOATPLANE:   SPONSORS, AFFILIATES, AND PARTNERS:   OUR WAN PODCAST GEAR:   FOLLOW US  ---------------------------------------------------   Twitter:  Facebook:  Instagram:  TikTok:  Twitch:   MUSIC CREDIT --------------------------------------------------- Intro: Laszlo - Supernova Video Link:  iTunes Download Link:  Artist Link:   Outro: Approaching Nirvana - Sugar High Video Link:  Listen on Spotify:  Artist Link:   Intro animation by MBarek Abdelwassaa  Monitor And Keyboard by vadimmihalkevich / CC BY 4.0   Mechanical RGB Keyboard by BigBrotherECE / CC BY 4.0  Mouse Gamer free Model By Oscar Creativo / CC BY 4.0   CHAPTERS --------------------------------------------------- 0:00 Intro 1:30 Less of a gongshow 2:20 Our choice of card 3:58 RDNA3 5:40 Jake's upgrade (feat Arlo)  7:40 Luke's upgrade  8:42 Linus' turn 10:55 Something HAD to go wrong 13:20 Everything's FINE  14:54 The Halo test 16:16 Outro
transcript: (keyboard thumping) Perfect. Completely unresponsive, hard-locked system. This is great. I finally finish the Intel Arc challenge, I go back to my RTX 3090, I'm like, "Yeah, I'm gonna have a stable system again." And actually, I've had nothing but problems with it. But I told myself, between Nvidia's price hikes and their attitude, I am skipping the 40-series. Which leaves me with what for options? I mean, once upon a time, 15 years ago, I daily drove the Radeon 3870, but I haven't touched an AMD GPU, at least not in my daily driver system, for 15 years. Have they reached the point where they're usable? They've certainly reached the point where they're my only feasible option for an upgrade, so this is it. That's right, folks. It's time for the AMD challenge. Sponsored by Seasonic, I will be running AMD for the next 30 days, and I will be bringing along with me two of my very picky tech enthusiast friends, Jake and Luke to share with you our experience. So come along for the ride, and I hope you've got a great power supply. Did I mention this is brought to you by Seasonic? Because whether you're team green or team red these days, Oho, you're gonna need something pretty powerful. (upbeat music) In all seriousness, I am not really expecting this to be as much of a gong show as the Intel version was. AMD, unlike Intel, has been doing dedicated graphics for, well, ever since they acquired ATI, which is, I guess, over 15 years now. But in that time, their software team has made enormous strides in terms of both compatibility and performance. That is, at least, if the community's reviews of Radeon graphics cards are anything to go by. They've certainly ran into some challenges with the 7000-series. They had some issues with defective vapor chambers causing unusually high temperatures, but that shouldn't affect me because I'm not using an AMD reference card. So, with confidence, I am going ahead to... Why is this still on? You guys watched me turn it off. What can I say, I'm just a lot better at turning things on than turning them off. All three of us went with the R9 7900 XTX, so the more premium version. And you know, normally you don't look at the top tier card and go, "Hmm, yeah, that one's probably the better value." But somehow, AMD managed to pull it off. The 7900 XT is cut down so much, that for the $100 you're saving compared to the XTX, it really doesn't look like a very compelling option. The XTX on the other hand, as long as a major focus for you isn't ray traced titles, its performance in traditional games is extremely compelling. You can get more details about it in our full review of the 7900-series that we uploaded a little while back. Now of course, the card that we were covering was the reference card from AMD. This one, uh, is quite a bit beefier to the point where - [Jake] Oh god. - [Linus] we might actually have a clearance issue here. - [Jake] Oh god. - Jake, can I help you? - [Jake] I'm just oh-goding for the same reason you're oh-goding. We've come up with a solution. Massive thanks to Gigabyte for sending over this Aorus card. But I guess I get to use a reference card. Now, the last thing we want is for any of this coolant to get into our high quality Seasonic power supply. Did I mention they sponsored this video? So I'm just gonna put this high quality ShortCircuit Hoodie, very absorbent, in the way. And make sure that we don't get any water in it. Oh, this is gonna be so easy, because AMD's drivers are not gonna be a problem. At least, that's my hope, because in my review of this card I kind of committed to switching to team red, so I've really... Regardless of whether it's an Aorus card or a reference card, I really need this thing to be good. It uses AMD's RDNA 3 architecture, which is all new for the 7000-series. It brings with it a huge uplift in clock speed, CUs or compute units, AI accelerators, and, perhaps for me most importantly, their video encoding engine has gotten a complete overhaul, including support for AV1, which isn't supported on streaming platforms like Twitch yet, but will hopefully be coming very, very soon. One of the other things that's really cool about AMD's RDNA 3 cards, is, I mean, not necessarily gonna excite you from a performance standpoint, but could excite you from a cost standpoint. Instead of building these cards using a monolithic, or a single large die, they used a chiplet approach, similar to what they've done with their Ryzen CPUs. So instead of using the latest manufacturing process for the entire die, they actually used TSMC's 6nm for their memory and cache die since they found that there wasn't really a benefit to shrinking it down, and then they used their 5nm process for their compute die. So that's where you're actually still getting good scaling in terms of power consumption and performance. I mean, they're still really expensive, but like, guess we'll take the little "w"s when we can get them. Another thing we can do while we wait is refill the loop. Because the parts aren't actually here for my... (metal clanging) 7950X upgrade, I'm just gonna be running a bypass, so the GPU will not be water cooled during this experiment. This also allows me to, like, just go back to the 3090 if I decide ah, you know what, it's really not worth the extra performance. Jake, we cheated a little bit. He's actually already done his upgrade, we're shooting out of order. But what I found out is there's an extra set of holes in the middle. (laughing) - Wait, what, no. Oh, no. No, no. - [Jake] Yes. - No, we're not using a riser. I'm not catching that. - Okay, it's just gonna hit you then. I've got another one, here, you ready? Oh, thanks Windows, good timing Windows update. - Yeah, but then remember when you were doing the maintenance, you turned it on and off, and on and off like a bunch of times? - I guess this shouldn't be on right now. Okay. - [Jake] Just power it off, eh. - Why is this still on? - I think you corrupted your own Windows install. (Linus sighing) Got a Windows install disc? - It's just, it's one of those things where, like, honestly, I don't know, 95 times out of 100, you interrupt a Windows update, it'll, like, figure it out. - It's fine, yeah. Except when you're trying to film a video and you have a GPU on a riser outside your computer and you've got water potentially dripping. - There's no water dripping. - It's after the end of the day and it's overtime now. (Linus sighing and swearing) - Here's the update. We have a completely different GPU with a completely different drive. We have removed the drive that we think has the corrupted Windows on it, and we are still getting that same error. You know what it reminds me of? It's behaving like the boot loader is on one storage device, but then the actual operating system files are on another. - On two drives? - Yeah. Which I've seen. - On both of them? - Yeah, which I've seen a lot of times. But the problem is that I don't have two storage devices in here. - No. - So what is happening? - Don't know. - I'm at a loss, man. Total loss. - Especially since we put the 3090 back in, like in the slot, and it still didn't go. (sighing) It's, like, an hour and a half later, I think. And the computer's working now. So what ended up being the problem, I'm pretty sure, is there was some weird configuration in the BIOS because of the RAID setup.
